density.note: Liquid propane at room temperature requires ~8.5 atm pressure (typical tank pressure); less dense than water

evaporationCoefficient.note: Hertz-Knudsen α coefficient. High value - nonpolar hydrocarbon with weak intermolecular forces. Range 0.01-1.0.

latentHeatOfFusion.note: Energy to melt frozen propane at -187.7°C

volumetricExpansionCoefficient.note: Significant thermal expansion (why tanks must not be overfilled)

antoineCoefficients.TminC_note: EMPIRICALLY VERIFIED RANGE MINIMUM: The Antoine coefficients were experimentally validated down to this temperature. Calculations below this are extrapolated (smooth curve continues, but accuracy may degrade).
antoineCoefficients.TmaxC_note: EMPIRICALLY VERIFIED RANGE MAXIMUM: The Antoine coefficients were experimentally validated up to this temperature. Calculations above this are extrapolated (smooth curve continues, but accuracy may degrade).
antoineCoefficients.source: Propane vapor pressure from liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) thermodynamic handbooks; valid for pressurized liquid storage conditions.
antoineCoefficients.note: Propane boils at -42.1°C at 1 atm. Stored as pressurized liquid in tanks (~8.5 atm at 25°C). Accurate vapor pressure essential for tank safety.

flammability.note: Liquid propane vaporizes rapidly when released from pressure; vapor is extremely flammable

vaporPressure.note: High vapor pressure at room temperature; stored under pressure
